text:
The Geographical Pivot of History
By H. J. Mackinder
The Geographical Journal, Vol. 23, No. 4 (Apr, 1904), 421-437.

When historians in the remote future look back on the past few centuries, they may well describe the last 400 years as the Columbian epoch, ending soon after 1900.  Geographical exploration is nearly over, and geography must now turn to intensive survey and philosophical synthesis. In 400 years, the world map has been completed, and even the polar regions offer little scope for dramatic discoveries.  The 20th century marks the end of a great historical epoch not just because of this mapping achievement, but because the world has been almost completely politically appropriated.  Missionaries, conquerors, farmers, miners, and engineers have followed explorers so closely that few regions remain unclaimed.  The Columbian epoch contrasts with preceding ages in that European expansion met negligible resistance, whereas medieval Christendom was confined and threatened by external barbarism. From now on, in the post-Columbian age, we will deal with a closed global political system.  Social forces, instead of dissipating into unknown space and barbaric chaos, will reverberate globally, shattering weak political and economic elements.  This new reality is diverting statesmen's attention from territorial expansion to the struggle for relative efficiency.

For the first time, we can correlate larger geographical and historical generalizations, perceive the proportions of events on the world stage, and seek a formula to express geographical causation in universal history.  This formula should illuminate current international politics.  The phrase 'westward march of empire' is a rudimentary attempt.  I will describe the physical features I believe most coercive of human action, and present historical phases organically connected with them, even when unknown to geography.  My aim is not regional geography, but to exhibit human history as part of the world organism. I acknowledge this is only one aspect of the truth and avoid excessive materialism. Man initiates, but nature controls.  I focus on general physical control.  Professor Freeman argued that significant history is that of Mediterranean and European races. This is true regarding the origin of dominant ideas, but it limits thought.  National ideas arise under pressure of common tribulation and resistance to external force.  The idea of England was forged by Danish and Norman conquerors; the idea of France by Huns and the Hundred Years' War; the idea of Christendom by Roman persecutions and the Crusades; the idea of the United States by the War of Independence; the idea of the German Empire by the Franco-Prussian War.  Literary history, by focusing on ideas and civilization, overlooks the elemental pressures that excite the efforts in which ideas are nourished.  A repellent personality unites his enemies, and Europe achieved her civilization under pressure from external barbarism.  Consider Europe and its history as subordinate to Asia, for European civilization is the outcome of the secular struggle against Asiatic invasion.

section: The Contrast of Russia and Western Europe
text: The vast area of Russia contrasts sharply with the smaller territories of Western Europe.  Physically, Russia's unbroken eastern lowland contrasts with the complex mountains, islands, and peninsulas of the west.  This seems to correlate environment and political organization, especially given Russia's uniform climate of cold winters and hot summers.  However, historical maps reveal that the coincidence of European Russia with the Eastern Plain is recent.  Earlier, two groups of states usually divided Russia into northern and southern political systems.  The orographical map doesn't reflect the physical contrast that controlled human movement and settlement in Russia until recently.  Rain follows the winter snowmelt, peaking in May and June near the Black Sea, but in July and August near the Baltic and White Seas. The southern late summer is a period of drought.  Consequently, the north and northwest were forested and marshy, while the south and southeast were boundless grassy steppe with trees only along rivers.  The dividing line ran diagonally northeastward from the northern Carpathians to a point in the Urals nearer its southern end. Moscow lies just north of this line, on the forest side.  Outside Russia, the forest boundary ran westward through the center of the 800-mile-wide European isthmus between the Baltic and Black Seas.  In peninsular Europe, woods spread through northern Germany, while steppes extended through the Transylvanian basin of the Carpathians, up the Danube through modern Romania to the Iron Gates.  A detached steppe area, the Puszta, occupied the Hungarian plain, surrounded by forested Carpathian and Alpine mountains.  In western Russia, clearing forests, draining marshes, and tilling steppes have blurred this formerly significant distinction.

meta.use_case: Analyzing the influence of geography on political boundaries

text: Earlier Russia and Poland were established in forest glades.  From the 5th to 16th centuries, Turanian nomads—Huns, Avars, Bulgarians, Magyars, Khazars, Patzinaks, Cumans, Mongols, Kalmuks—entered the steppe through the gateway between the Urals and the Caspian Sea.  Attila's Huns settled in the Puszta, the Danubian steppe outlier, and attacked settled peoples north, west, and south.  Modern history can be viewed as a commentary on the changes resulting from these raids.  The Angles and Saxons may have been driven to Britain by them. Franks, Goths, and Romans were forced to unite at Chalons against the Asiatics.

meta.use_case: Understanding the impact of nomadic invasions on European development

text: were unconsciously; welding together modern France: Venice against large part P0 LA N D Zaporogian "Cossacks quite THE GEOGRAPHICAL PIVOT OF HISTORY. 427 was founded from the destruction of Aquileia and Padua and even the Papacy owed a decisive prestige to the successful mediation of Leo with Attila at Milan. Such was the harvest of results produced by a cloud of ruthless and idealess horsemen sweeping over the un- impeded plain ~a blow, a8 it were, from the Agiatic hammer striking freely through the vacant gpace. The Huns were followed by the Avars. It wa8 for a marchland againgt these that Austria was founded, and Vienna fortified, a8 the result of the campaigns of Charlemagne. The Magyar came next, and by incesgant raiding from his steppe base in Hungary increased the significance of tbe Austrian outpost, 80 drawing the political focus of Germany east- ward to the margin of the realm. The Bulgarian established a ruling caste south of the Danube, and has left his name upon the map, although his language has yielded to that of bis-Slavonic subjecte_ Perhaps the longest and most effective occupation of the Russian steppe proper was that of the Khazar8, who were contemporaries of the Saracen movement tbe Arab geographers knew the Caspian a8 the Khazar sea. In the ed, however; new hordes arrived from Mongolia, and for two centuries Russia in the northern forest 66 9) was held tributary to the Mongol Khang of Kipchak, or the Steppe;' and Russian development was thus delayed and biasged at a time when the remainder of Europe wa8 rapidly advancing: It ghould be noted that the rivers running from the Forest to the Black and Oaspian seas cross the whole breadth of the steppe-land of the nomads, and that from time to time there were trangient move- ments their courses at right to the movement of the horsemen. Thus the missionaries of Greek Ohristianity ascended the Dnieper to Kief; just a8 beforehand the Norse Varangians had descended the same river on their way to Constantinople. Still earlier, the Teutonic Gothg appear for a moment upon the Dniester, having crossed Europe from the shores of the Baltic in the same south-eastward direction_ But these are passing episodes which d0 not invalidate the broader generalization. For a thousand years a geries of horce-riding peopleg emerged from Asia tbrough the broad interval between the Ural mountaing and the Caspian sea, rode through the open spaces of southern Russia, and struck home into Hungary in the very heart of the European peningula, shaping by the necessity of opposing them the history of each of the great peoples around_~the Rugsians, the Germang, the French, the Italians, and the Byzantine Greeks That stimu- lated healthy and powerful reaction, instead of orushing opposition under a widespread despotism, wa8 due to the fact that the mobility of their power wa8 Cunditioned by the steppes, and necessarily ceased in the gurrounding forests and mountains. A rival mobility of power wa8 that of the Vikings in their boats. Descending from Scandinavia both upon the northern and the southern Pope great great path angles along they 428 THE GEOGRAPHICAL PIVOT OF HISTORY shores of Europe, penetrated inland by the river ways. But the scope of their action was limited, broadly speaking, their power was effective only in the neighbourhood of the water: Thus the settled of , Europe gripped between two pressures--that of the Asiatic nomads from the east, and on the other three sides that 0f the pirates from the sea. From its very nature neither pressure was over- whelming, and both therefore were stimulative. It is noteworthy that the formative influence of the Scandinavians was second only in nificance to that of the nomads, for under their attack both England and France made moves towards while the of Italy was broken by them. In earlier times, Rome had mobilized the power of her settled peoples by means of her roads, but the Roman roads had fallen into and were not replaced until the eighteenth century: It is likely that even the Hunnish invasion was by no means the first of the Asiatic series.

The Scythians of the Homeric and Hero- dotian accounts, drinking the milk of mares, obviously practised the same arts of life, were probably of the same race a8 the later inbabitants of the steppe. The Celtic element in the river-names Don, Donetz, Dneiper , Dneister, and Danube may possibly betoken the passage of peoples of similar habits, though not of identical race, but it is not unlikely that the Celts came merely from the northern forests, like the Goths and Varangians of a later time. The of population, however, which the anthropologists characterize a8 Cephalic, driven westward from Brachy-Cephalic Asia through Central Europe into France, is apparently intrusive between the northern, western, and southern Dolico-Cephalic populations, and may very * probably have been derived from Asia. The full meaning of Asiatic influence upon Europe is not, however, discernible until wO come to the Mongol invasions of the ffteenth century but before we analyze the essential facts concerning these, it is desirable to shift our geographical view-point from Europe, s0 that we may consider the Old World in its entirety. It is obvious that, since tbe rainfall is derived from the sea, the heart of the greatest land-mass is likely to be relatively We are not, therefore, sur- prised to find that two-thirds of all the world' s population is concen- trated in relatively small areas along the marging of the great continent in Europe, beside the Atlantic ocean; in the Indies and China; beside the Indian and Pacific oceans. A vast belt of almost uninhabited, because practically rainlegs, land extenda as the Sabara completely across Northern Africa into Arabia. Central and Southern Africa were almost a8 completely severed from Europe and Asia throughout the greater of history a8 were the Americas and Australia. In fact, the southern boundary of Europe was and is the Sahara rather than the See 'The Raccs of Europe;' by Prof. W. Z. Ripley (Kegan Paul, 1900) they for, peoples lay 8ig- long unity, unity decaY, and wedge great Brachy- dry: prised part THE GEOGRAPHICAL PIVOT OF HISTORY. 429 Mediterranean, for it is the desert which divides the black man from the white. The continuous land-mags of Euro-Agia thus included between the ocean and the desert measures 21,000,000 square miles, or half of all the land on the globe, if we exclude from reckoning the deserts of Sahara and Arabia: There are many detached deserts scat- tered through from Syria and Persia north-eastward to Manchuria, but no such continuous vacancy a8 to be comparable with the Sahara. On the other band, Euro-Asia is characterized by & very remarkable distribution of river drainage. Throughout an immenge of the centre and north, the rivers bave been practically useless for purposes of human communication with the outer world_ The Volga, the and the Jaxartes drain into salt lakes ; the Obi, the Yenesei, and the Lena into the frozen ocean of the north: These are six 0f the Fig Darbishire & Stanford Ltd. The Oxford Geog' Institute. CONTINENTAL AND ARCTIC DRAINAGE EQUAL AREA PROJECTION greatest rivers in the world. There are many gmaller but still con - siderable streams in the same area, such a8 the Tarim and the Helmund, which gimilarly fail to reach the ocean_ Thus the core of Euro-Agia, although mottled with desert patches, is on the whole a steppe-land supplying a wide-spread if often scanty pasture, and there are not a few river-fed oases in it, but it is wholly unpenetrated by waterways from tbe ocean. In other words, wO have in thig immense area all the conditiong for the maintenance 0f &a sparse, but in the aggregate considerable, population of horge-riding anl camel-riding nomads. Their realm is limited northward by a broad belt of gub-arctic forest and marsh, wherein tbe climate is too rigorous, except at the eastern and western extremities, for the development of agricultural settlements In the east the forests extend gouthward to the Pacific coast in the Amur Asia, portion Oxu8, 430 THE GEOGRAPHICAL PIVOT OF HISTORY. land and Manchuria: Similarly in the west,in prehistoric Europe, forest was the predominant vegetation. Thus framed in to the north-east, north, and north-west, the steppe8 continuously for 4000 miles from the Pussta8 of Hungary to the Little Gobi of Manchuria, and, except in their westernmost extremity, are untraversed by rivers draining to an accessible ocean, for W0 may the very recent efforts to trade to the mouths of the Obi and Yenisei. In Europe; Western Siberia, and Western Turkestan the steppe lands lie low, in some places below the level of the gea. Further to east, in Mongolia, extend over plateaux ; but the passage from the one level to the other, over the naked, unscarped lower ranges of the arid heart-land, pregents little difficulty: The hordes which ultimately fell upon Europe in the middle of the fourteenth century gathered their first force 8000 miles away on the high steppes of Mongolia.

meta.theme: Geography and Nomadic Power in Eurasia

text: In the 0a808, it is therefore thinly peopled. In some degree it partakes of the characteristics both of the marginal belt and of the central area of Euro-Asia. It is mainly devoid of forest, is patched with desert, and is therefore suitable for the operations of the nomad. Dominantly, however, it is marginal, for sea-gulfs and oceanic rivers open it to sea-power, and permit of the exercise of such power from it. As a consequence, periodically throughout history, we have here had empires belonging essentially to the marginal series, based on the agricultural populations of the great 0a808 of Babylonia and Egypt, and in free water-communication with the civilized worlds of the Mediterranean and the Indies. But, as we should expect, these empires have been subject to an unparalleled series of revolutions, some due to Scythian, Turkish, and Mongol raids from Central Asia; others to the efforts of the Mediterranean peoples to conquer the overland ways from the western to the eastern Ocean. Here is the weakest spot in the girdle of early civilizations, for the isthmus of Suez divided sea-power into Eastern and Western; and the arid wastes of Persia advancing from Central Asia to the Persian Gulf gave constant opportunity for nomad-power to strike home to the ocean edge, dividing India and China, on the one hand, from the Mediterranean world on the other. Whenever the Babylonian, the Syrian, and the Egyptian oases were weakly held, the steppe-peoples could treat the open tablelands of Iran and Asia Minor as forward posts whence to strike through the Punjab into India, through Syria into Egypt, and over the broken bridge of the Bosporus and Dardanelles into Hungary. Vienna stood in the gateway of Inner Europe, withstanding the nomadic raids, both those which came by the direct road through the Russian steppe, and those which came by the way to south of the Black and Caspian seas. Here we have illustrated the essential difference between the Saracen and the Turkish controls of the Nearer East. The Saracens were a branch of the Semitic race, essentially peoples of the Euphrates and Nile and of the smaller oases of Lower Asia. They created a great empire by availing themselves of the two mobilities permitted by their land--that of the horse and camel on the one hand, that of the ship on the other. At different times their fleets controlled both the Mediterranean as far as Spain, and the Indian ocean to the Malay islands. From their strategically central position between the eastern and western oceans, they attempted the conquest of all the marginal lands of the Old World, imitating Alexander and anticipating Napoleon. They could even threaten the steppe land.

meta.theme: Geopolitical History and the Pivot of Power

text: Wholly distinct from Arabia as from Europe, India, and China were the Turanian pagans from the closed heart of Asia, the Turks who destroyed the Saracen civilization. Mobility upon the ocean is the natural rival of horse and camel mobility in the heart of the continent. It was upon navigation of oceanic rivers that was based the Potamic stage of civilization, that of China on the Yangtse, that of India on the Ganges, that of Babylonia on the Euphrates, that of Egypt on the Nile. It was essentially upon the navigation of the Mediterranean that was based what has been described as the Thalassic stage of civilization, that of the Greeks and Romans. The Saracens and the Vikings held sway by navigation of the oceanic coasts. The all-important result of the discovery of the Cape road to the Indies was to connect the western and eastern coastal navigations of Euro-Asia, even though by a circuitous route, and thus in some measure to neutralize the strategic advantage of the central position of the steppe-nomads by pressing upon them in rear. The revolution commenced by the mariners of the Columbian generation endowed Christendom with the widest possible mobility of power, short of a winged mobility. The one and continuous ocean enveloping the divided and insular lands is, of course, the geographical condition of ultimate unity in the command of the sea, and of the whole theory of modern strategy and policy as expounded by such writers as Captain Mahan and Mr. Spencer Wilkinson. The broad political effect was to reverse the relations of Europe and Asia, for whereas in the Middle Ages Europe was between an impassable desert to south, an unknown ocean to west, and forested wastes to north and north-east, and in the east and south-east was constantly threatened by the superior mobility of the horsemen and camelmen, she now emerged upon the world, multiplying more than thirty-fold the sea surface and coastal lands to which she had access, and wrapping her influence round the Euro-Asiatic land-power which had hitherto threatened her very existence. New Europes were created in the vacant lands discovered in the midst of the waters, and what Britain and Scandinavia were to Europe in the earlier time, that have America and Australia, and in some measure even Trans-Saharan Africa, now become to Euro-Asia. Britain, Canada, the United States, South Africa, Australia, and Japan are now a ring of outer and insular bases for sea-power and commerce, inaccessible to the land-power of Euro-Asia.

meta.theme: Shifting Power Dynamics: Sea Power vs. Land Power
meta.use_case: Analysis of the impact of maritime technology and exploration

The particular combinationg of brought into balance are not material ; my contention is that from a geographical of view are likely to rotate round the 'Turkey, replaces great graphical parted law equi- poise point bridge May system Cape They they power they point THE GEOGRAPHICAL PIVOT OF HISTORY_DISCUSSION. 437 pivot state, which is always likely to be great, but with limited mobility a8 compared with the gurrounding marginal and ingular powere. I bave as a geographer. The actual balance of political power at any given time is, of course, the product, on the oe band, of geographical conditions, both economic and ttrategic, and, o the, other hand; of the relative number, virility, equipment, and organization of the competing peoples; In proportion a8 these quantities are accurately estimated are we likely to adjust differences without the crude resort to arms. And the geographical quantities in the calculation are more meagurable and more nearly constant than the human. Hence we should expect to find our formula apply equally to history and to present politics. The social movements of all times have played around essen- tially the eame phygical features, for I doubt whether the progressive desiccation of Asia and Africa, even if proved, hag in historical times vitally altered the human environment.

The westward march of empire appears to me to have been a ghort rotation of marginal power round tbe south-western and western edge of the pivotal area. The Nearer, Middle, and Far Eastern questions relate to the unstable equilibrium of inner and outer powers in thoge of the marginal crescent where local power i8, at present, more or les8 negligible. In cnclugion, it may be well expressly to out that the sub- stitution of gome new control of the inland area for that of Russia would not tend to reduce the geographical significance of the pivot tion Were the Chinese; for instance, organized by the Japanese, to overthrow the Russian Empire and conquer its territory, might constitute tbe yellow to the world's freedom just because would add an oceanic frontage to the regources of the continent, an advantage a8 denied to the Russian tenant of the pivot Before the reading of the paper, the PRESIDENT said We are alwayg very glad when we can induce our friend Mr. Mackinder to address u8 o any subject, because all he says to us is sure to be interesting ad original and valuable.
